quiz.title: Unit 6: Monopoly (Quiz 5)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Applied Scenarios, Multi-Market Analysis, and Comparative Outcomes
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Multi-Part Monopoly Problems, Cross-Market Effects, Game Theory Insights, Efficiency Trade-offs

questions.question: If a monopolist discovers a way to lower its marginal cost at all output levels, the profit-maximizing output will ____ and price will ____.
questions.explanation: Lower MC shifts the MC curve down, intersecting MR at a higher quantity. With a downward-sloping demand curve, higher quantity means lower price.

questions.question: A monopoly faces demand P = 120 – 3Q and has TC = 400 + 10Q. What is the profit-maximizing price?
questions.explanation: MR = 120 – 6Q. MC = 10. Set MR = MC: 120 – 6Q = 10 → Q ≈ 18.33. P = 120 – 3(18.33) ≈ 120 – 55 = $65. Wait, that’s $65. Let’s check math: 120 – 6Q = 10 → 110 = 6Q → Q = 18.33. P = 120 – 55 = 65. So answer is B. But options include $75. Possibly miscalculation: P = 120 – 3(18.33) = 65. If they round Q=18.33 down? Let’s keep B as correct.

questions.question: A monopolist selling in two separate markets with different demand elasticities will maximize profit by:
options: Charging the same price in both markets
Setting MR equal in both markets
Setting MR = MC in each market
Selling only in the more elastic market
questions.explanation: To maximize total profit, the monopolist should allocate output so that MR = MC in each market (third-degree price discrimination).

questions.question: Compared to a competitive market, the deadweight loss from monopoly represents:
options: A transfer from consumers to producers
questions.explanation: Deadweight loss is the loss of total surplus (consumer + producer) due to reduced output below the socially optimal level.

questions.question: A monopolist will always produce on the ____ portion of its demand curve.
questions.explanation: MR is positive only when demand is elastic (|Ed| > 1). Since profit max occurs where MR = MC > 0, output must be in the elastic region.

questions.question: If a monopoly is broken up into several smaller competing firms, market output will ____ and price will ____.
questions.explanation: Breaking up a monopoly increases competition, leading to higher output and lower price (closer to the competitive equilibrium).

questions.question: A monopolist faces a linear demand curve. If it maximizes revenue instead of profit, it will produce where:
questions.explanation: Revenue is maximized where marginal revenue equals zero (top of the total revenue curve).

questions.question: For a natural monopoly, the socially optimal (allocatively efficient) price is where:
questions.explanation: Allocative efficiency requires P = MC, but for a natural monopoly, P = MC < ATC, causing losses if unsubsidized.

questions.question: A monopolist is currently producing where demand is unit elastic. To increase profit, it should:
questions.explanation: At unit elastic demand, MR = 0. Since MC > 0, MR < MC, so decreasing output will increase profit.

questions.question: If government imposes a per-unit tax on a monopolist, the burden of the tax:
options: Is shared between consumers and the monopolist
Is absorbed entirely by reduced output
questions.explanation: Unlike in perfect competition, the tax burden in monopoly is shared between consumers (higher price) and the monopolist (lower profit), depending on elasticity.

scoreMessages.90: Superior applied analysis of monopoly behavior, tax effects, and market comparisons.

scoreMessages.50: Fair; revisit tax incidence, elasticity regions, and natural monopoly regulation.
